title: 110_s1881
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Americans with Disabilities Act Restoration Act of 2007". Congress finds that the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 intended to establish a clear prohibition of discrimination based on disability, but Supreme Court decisions have narrowed its protection. Congress recognized that individuals with disabilities have the right to fully participate in society, but prejudice often prevents them from doing so. Congress recognized that individuals with disabilities face barriers to full participation in society due to prejudice and antiquated attitudes. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 modeled its definition of disability on the broad conception of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which includes both actual and perceived limitations imposed by society. The Supreme Court's decision in School Board of Nassau County v. Arline highlighted the societal impact of myths and fears about disability. Congress, in the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, recognized that adverse actions based on physical or mental impairments are often unrelated to the limitations caused by the impairment itself. However, the Supreme Court's ruling in Toyota Motor Manufacturing, Kentucky, Inc. v. Williams interpreted the definition of disability strictly, creating a demanding standard for qualification. The Supreme Court in Toyota Motor Manufacturing, Kentucky, Inc. v. Williams narrowed the definition of disability, eliminating coverage for individuals who have mitigated their impairments. The purpose of this Act is to restore the broad scope of protection under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The Act aims to restore broad protection against discrimination under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, responding to Supreme Court decisions that have narrowed the class of individuals protected. It clarifies that protection is available for all individuals facing adverse treatment based on an actual or perceived impairment. The Protection and Clarification Act of 2020 expands the scope of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 by ensuring protection for individuals facing adverse treatment due to actual or perceived impairments, prejudiced attitudes, societal barriers, and the failure to provide reasonable accommodations. The Protection and Clarification Act of 2020 expands the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 to protect individuals from adverse treatment due to impairments, prejudiced attitudes, societal barriers, and lack of reasonable accommodations. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to emphasize that physical and mental disabilities are natural parts of human experience and should not hinder a person's right to fully participate in society. It also acknowledges the discrimination faced by individuals with disabilities and their history of unequal treatment and powerlessness in society. Individuals with disabilities have faced unequal treatment and powerlessness in society. Classifications and selection criteria excluding them should be strongly disfavored and only permitted for compelling reasons, not based on prejudice or stereotypes. SEC. 4. DISABILITY DEFINED. Section 3 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (42 U.S.C. 12102) is amended to define "disability" as a physical or mental impairment, a record of such impairment, or being regarded as having such an impairment. The determination of impairment should not consider the use or impact of mitigating measures. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 defines "disability" as a physical or mental impairment, a record of such impairment, or being regarded as having such an impairment. Mitigating measures, such as treatments or accommodations, should not be considered in determining impairment. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 defines "disability" as a physical or mental impairment, a record of such impairment, or being regarded as having such an impairment. Mitigating measures, such as treatments or accommodations, should not be considered in determining impairment. The Act further elaborates on the definitions of mental and physical impairments, specifying various disorders and conditions that fall under each category. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 defines "disability" as a physical or mental impairment, a record of such impairment, or being regarded as having such an impairment. It specifies various categories of impairments including respiratory, cardiovascular, reproductive, digestive, genitourinary, hemic and lymphatic, skin, and endocrine. The Act also explains what constitutes a record of impairment and being regarded as having an impairment. SEC. 5. ADVERSE ACTION.

The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to include discrimination against individuals using mitigating measures as discrimination under the Act.

SEC. 6. DISCRIMINATION ON THE BASIS OF DISABILITY.

Section 102 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to clarify discrimination against individuals on the basis of disability.

SEC. 7. QUALIFIED INDIVIDUAL. SEC. 7. QUALIFIED INDIVIDUAL. Section 103(a) of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to clarify that the individual alleging discrimination must be a qualified individual with a disability. Section 501 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to ensure broad construction of the Act for comprehensive prohibition of discrimination. Regulations must be issued within 180 days to implement the provisions of the Act. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to broaden the prohibition of discrimination. The Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board will issue additional guidelines to supplement existing design requirements. Federal regulations and guidance for implementing the Act, including defining disability, will be respected. The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is amended to broaden discrimination prohibition. Federal regulations and guidance, including defining disability, will be respected in actions under this Act.
